article.title: Thermal properties of graphene from path-integral simulations

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the internal energy per atom of graphene at different temperatures?
choices: As system size increases, internal energy per atom decreases at all temperatures.
At lower temperatures, the internal energy per atom shows a more significant dependence on system size.
The internal energy per atom remains constant with increasing system size at high temperatures.
The convergence of internal energy with system size is independent of temperature.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the difference in zero-point energy between the NPT and constant Ap simulations primarily indicate?
choices: The effect of pressure on the kinetic energy of the system.
The influence of zero-point lattice expansion on the system\'s energy.
A significant change in the anharmonicity of the lattice vibrations at 0K.
The breakdown of the harmonic approximation at low temperatures.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which term dominates the temperature dependence of graphene\'s internal energy in the region below 40K?
choices: The linear term (proportional to T)
The quadratic term (proportional to T²)
The cubic term (proportional to T³)
The zero-point energy (independent of T)

multiple_choice_question.text: What causes the observed decrease in the in-plane area (Ap) of graphene at temperatures below 1000K?
choices: Thermal contraction of the C-C bonds.
Increased out-of-plane atomic displacements due to bending.
Negative thermal expansion of the real surface area (A).
A decrease in the zero-point motion of the carbon atoms.

multiple_choice_question.text: What trend is observed for the temperature (Tm) at which the in-plane area of graphene reaches its minimum (Ap) with increasing system size?
choices: Tm decreases with increasing system size.
Tm remains constant regardless of system size.
Tm increases with increasing system size.
The trend of Tm with system size is not consistent.

multiple_choice_question.text: How does the behavior of the thermal expansion coefficient (α) differ from that of the in-plane thermal expansion coefficient (αp) in graphene?
choices: α is always positive, while αp becomes negative at low temperatures.
α shows a minimum at a finite temperature, while αp decreases monotonically.
Both α and αp converge to a non-zero value at low temperatures.
α is size-dependent, while αp is independent of system size.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary reason for the difference in elastic energy between the NPT and constant Ap simulations?
choices: The difference in computational methods used for each ensemble.
The fixed area in the constant Ap simulations prevents relaxation and leads to higher elastic energy.
The NPT simulations allow for volume expansion, resulting in lower elastic energy.
The different treatment of zero-point energy in each simulation method.

multiple_choice_question.text: Up to what temperature does the harmonic approximation (HA) reasonably describe the specific heat of graphene obtained from PIMD simulations?
At low temperatures, the specific heat of graphene exhibits a behavior proportional to T. What does this indicate about the dominant contribution to the specific heat in this regime?
choices: Out-of-plane acoustic vibrations (ZA)
In-plane acoustic vibrations (LA, TA)
Optical vibrations (LO, TO)
Electronic contributions

multiple_choice_question.text: The difference between the specific heat at constant pressure (Cp) and constant area (Cv) for graphene vanishes at two temperatures. What is the primary reason for this observation?
choices: The in-plane isothermal bulk modulus (Bp) becomes zero at these temperatures.
The in-plane thermal expansion coefficient (αp) changes sign at these temperatures.
Quantum effects become negligible at these temperatures.
The system undergoes a phase transition at these temperatures.
